Here's a mystery: compound bows that have "parallel limbs" do so to cancel out vibration imparted to the archer's bow-hand because each arm, of equal mass, moves in opposite directions as the bow shoots, and due to Newton's laws, each one cancels out the vibration from the other. But tuning forks, which have equal mass limbs that vibrate in opposite directions, can impart vibrations down their stems onto a surface. Why would two things that have essentially the same operating principle with regards to vibrating limbs (equal mass limbs vibrating in unison but in opposite directions) have such opposite effects?

I took a train to come back to Ontario, and a young girl wanted to sit beside me for this over two day trip.
She said this "greaser" was bothering her, and he moved up to the empty seat across the aisle from us.
He was verbally abusive, so I offered him a Tic-Tac and he took it and put it in his mouth.

I would like to point out that the mechanism for transferring energy into heat is not likely as simple as is described in the video. Energy is directly transferred into the vibration of the surface, which is transmitted to the surrounding air as sound compression waves. Ultimately, yes, these waves are damped by non-restorative frictional forces which turn mechanical energy into heat. If we want to increase the height of the dropped tic-tac by adding more energy to the system (as spinning the tic-tac does), we could also drop the tic-tac onto a vibrating surface such as a speaker.
My purpose for commenting here is that saying that energy is "lost to heat" is a simplification that has led to some interesting conclusions in the comments (such as using heat to increase the height of a dropped tic-tac, when there isn't a simple mechanism to convert the heat of the tic-tac or surface directly to mechanical energy). I think this is a valuable teaching moment for understanding more physical phenomena--ones that are exploited every day by engineers such as those working to reduce noise from mechanical systems to make our lives more pleasant!

When you turn on the faucetthe water in the sink is at a low profile as it rushes away from the point of impact at a high velocity, then it forms a defined ring where the water all of a sudden forms a higher profile at a lower velocity. This phenomenon is known as a hydraulic jump, and it is caused by the interaction of mass flow rate, turbulence, and energy conservation.

Isn't it interesting how it makes a definite ring where the water becomes higher rather than gradually raising as the water slows?

There aren't many good videos about hydraulic jumps online, so that could be a neat thing to look into as it is important for infrastructure design (ditches, culverts, roads, dams, channels, etc...)

I noticed something in the slow mo part that raises a question in the energy part of the equation. You said that if a normal ball is dropped that the bounce is never higher than the original drop. It will be less, which is true. I would say it can also be noted that if you watch a ball being bounced in slow motion that the first bounce will be a percentage of its drop and all the other bounces will be calculated as the same. In other words if a ball bounces 3 times, the first bounce will be at 3/4 the height it was initially dropped. The second bounce should be 1/2 the full distance of the drop and so forth.
I noticed that when the tic tac drops from whatever height it is set and does a small bounce, that the energy used for its second bounce is the height of what it could be calculated if it did a normal bounce. Sorry if it is confusing to explain. Let me try this way.
Tic tac drops from 4 inches, it does a normal bounce which would be a 3/4 the height of 4 inches, and the second drop would be 1/2 the distance.
Tic tack drops from 4 inches, but does not land on its end but at an angle so first bounce is cancelled out, but contains the energy and the second bounce is STILL at 1/2 the original distance it would have been if it had dropped normally.

Cool video, but please be careful with terms. You said you had a “theory” as to why a tic tac might do what it does but hadn’t “verified yet”. Hypothesis would be a better term for that. Why is it important? Well, when you use theory for something that really isn’t a theory (in science) you give credence to people who complain about real scientific theories by saying “it’s just a theory”. Remember, in science a theory is a well tested, falsifiable, and predictive explanation for some aspect of the natural world. It has been verified, many times. This affects how sand saltates along a beach or in a dune field. Rotation causes the grain hops to be higher and longer than they otherwise would be. It's probably also partly why sand can sting your face when the wind is strong enough - saltation alone can't get grains to lift more than a few cm, but if a spinning grain smashes into another spinning grain while they're in mid-hop, they can fly up into someone's face. And it only takes one grain to ruin your beach stroll.

White, B. R., and J. C. Schulz (1977), Magnus effect in saltation, J. Fluid Mech., 81(3), 497–512, doi:10.1017/S0022112077002183.

This reminds me of a fact I encountered that most flat things (like chocolate bars or smartphones) that are dropped such that they land relatively flat break on their second impact. The first impact causes rotation to make the first edge bounce up while the average velocity is still downwards. The second impact has the rotation and the downward velocity both acting to increase the impact hence the object is more likely to break.

been thinking about this and there's another angle which makes this behaviour possibly even more interesting. Tic tacs are very light and so one assumes a large proportion of their potential energy will be dissipated just by falling through air. If that is true then a high speed rotation is going to absorb even more of the potential and actually decrease it's overall bounce. I haven't found anything on the internet about the strange phenomenon I'm about to describe, so I really hope someone sees this comment and solve the mystery :D . I have an acoustic guitar with nylon strings (a very cheap guitar) and I have a Samsung Galxy J7 (the older model, not the one launched in 2017). One day, from boredom, I placed my cellphone between the strings and the guitar hole (I don't know its name ) with the screen facing upwards (I had my guitar over my lap and I was able to look the strings) and the "north" of the phone was aligned with the "north" of the guitar (the head). I strumed the strings and I saw that the strings (the 2nd one, the 4th one and, to a less extent, the 6th one) looked a little bit warped, like in slow-mo. It's really trippy. I tried putting my phone perpendicular to the strings and it didn't work. It only worked when the phone was parallel to the strings (It doesn't matter if it is upwards or downwards, just parallel). I also discovered that the effect was much stronger if you lowered the screen brightness to its minimum. I tried other phones, but it only seems to work with mine. If I had to guess, I would say it has something to do with the screen's framerate and the frecuency in which the strings vibrate. I don't know if the effect can be seen through a camera, I guess you'll have to adjust the framerates or something like that.

Oh, I definitely have an everyday mystery I wonder about as I go through life.

Question: Simply put, how does our ideal mathematical notion of a continuous line (like the real numbers imagined on a line) embed into our physical world? Are not all points on the ideal line accounted for, if reality itself isn't infinitely divisible into smaller sections?

Physicists say the smallest distance is the Planck length. But this means that our physical reality is made up of discrete amounts of this smallest distance, right? But in mathematics, we can infinitely divide a line into smaller sections. Therefore, if we superimpose the two on top of each other, wouldn't this mean that there are points on our ideal line that have absolutely no physical counterpart, say if that point lands at a distance that is a fraction of a Planck length?

To help visualize this, imagine drawing a line on paper. We label some points of interest, say 0, 1, 2, 3, and pi. Now, this physical line tries to capture/represent these distances. But, as I said above, if reality is ultimately discrete, then surely some points will be missed! They fall between the "gaps" that are the fractions of the Planck length!

Say, this kinda reminds me of trying to show that a number, say root 2, is irrational in that you cannot find two whole numbers that divide to it, unless if you find smaller whole numbers that divide to it.. Anyway, just a vague connection I had right now.

But anyway, this mystery :c

(note: If space itself were infinitely divisible as in ideal math, then I think this problem goes away?)

You could do this with good timing, or a more interesting way would be to drop a super-cooled object onto a hot, slightly bowled surface. If you find materials with the right thermal conductivity, thermal expansion/contraction, and probably freezing and boiling points, the surface would contract and pull itself taut as soon as the super-cooled object hits it and it starts heating up the object, catapulting the object up much  higher than it started.

Here's something interesting that everyone can try.  With one hand, hold a chocolate bar (still in its wrapper) at one end with the label facing up and the other end facing away from you.  Now gently flip the chocolate bar end to end just enough to catch the other end of the chocolate bar in your hand.  In most cases that flip will not only rotate end to end.  But you'll also notice that the top label of the chocolate bar will still be facing UP.  Shouldn't the label now be facing down?  OK, now see if you can flip that chocolate bar so the label winds up on the bottom when you catch the other end (which is what you would expect to happen).   It takes some practice.  Plus, when you're done you can eat your experiment!  Happy flipping.  -Dave

My own theory before watching the video: when it touches the ground, it's most likely going to be at an angle. Since the tic tac is elongated and rounded at the ends, it's center of mass will be outside of the footprint. This means that when they touch the ground the first time, a portion of the energy, portion which will depend on the exact angle it is when touching the ground, will be converted in rotational energy as the tic tac will bounce low but will be spinning. On the second bounce, the tic tac will be falling slowly (since the first bounce is low), and have a lot of rotational energy, which will be converted back into a higher bounce as one end of the tic tac strikes the ground while spinning fast.

I cannot explain, however, how a tic tac could bounce higher than it's drop point unless a spin is induced before you let it fall.
